question: Will Cathy Harris still be listed as chairing the Merit Systems Protection Board on March 31, 2025?
description: The Hill: [Federal judge reinstates employee appeals board member fired by Trump](https://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/5151616-federal-judge-orders-reinstatement-of-merit-systems-protection-board-member/)
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Federal board halts firings of six probationary employees amid Trump cuts**
The Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) has granted a request from the U.S. Office of Special Counsel (OSC) to halt the termination of six probationary government employees amid the Trump administration's efforts to slash the federal workforce. The move was in response to a request from OSC head Hampton Dellinger, who argued that the firings were probably illegal and recommended that they be halted pending an investigation. The MSPB said that the request for a 45-day stay of the terminations was appropriate 'while OSC further investigates their complaints.' Democracy Forward president and CEO Skye Perryman called the decision 'the correct result of a clearly unlawful and massively disruptive action by the Trump administration.' The decision could have wider implications for the thousands of probationary employees fired in recent weeks, and OSC is considering ways to seek relief for a broader group.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 10:16 AM
Source:[washingtonpost.com](https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2025/02/26/probationary-employee-firings-trump-musk-doge/)

**Q4 2024 Merit Medical Systems Inc Earnings Call Transcript**
Merit Medical Systems' fourth-quarter 2024 earnings conference call was held on February 25, 2025. The call was led by Fred Lampropoulos, the company's Founder, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer. He was joined by Raul Parra, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer, and Brian Lloyd, Chief Legal Officer and Corporate Secretary. Brian Lloyd began the call by stating that the presentation contains forward-looking statements that receive safe harbor protection under federal securities laws, as required by law.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 05:13 AM
Source:[GuruFocus](https://www.gurufocus.com/news/2715263/q4-2024-merit-medical-systems-inc-earnings-call-transcript)

**US agency halts Trump administration's firing of six government employees**
The Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) has halted the terminations of six federal government employees who were targeted for firing by the Trump administration. The decision, made at the request of Hampton Dellinger, the head of the U.S. Office of Special Counsel, will stay the employees' terminations for 45 days. Dellinger argued that the agencies that employed the employees acted unlawfully by firing them, and that they misused the employees' probationary status to carry out de facto reductions-in-force. Ray Limon, the board's other Democratic member, agreed, saying that there were 'reasonable grounds to believe that each of the six agencies engaged in a prohibited personnel practice.' Dellinger welcomed the ruling, saying that his office 'will continue to pursue allegations of unlawful personnel actions, which can include asking MSPB for relief for a broader group of fired probationary employees.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 05:01 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/us-agency-halts-trump-administrations-045622976.html)

**Merit Medical Systems, Inc. (MMSI) Q4 2024 Earnings Call Transcript**
Merit Medical Systems, Inc. (MMSI) held a Q4 2024 earnings call on February 25, 2025. The call was led by Fred Lampropoulos, Founder, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer, who was joined by Raul Parra, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer, and Brian Lloyd, Chief Legal Officer and Corporate Secretary. Brian Lloyd noted that the presentation contains forward-looking statements that receive safe harbor protection under federal securities laws, and that actual results may differ from expectations due to risks and uncertainties. The call was recorded and will be available on the company's website for replay.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 03:39 AM
Source:[Seeking Alpha](https://seekingalpha.com/article/4761989-merit-medical-systems-inc-mmsi-q4-2024-earnings-call-transcript)

**Amid federal layoffs, US Merit Systems Protection Board sees dramatic spike in appeals from feds - WTOP News**
The U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board has seen a dramatic spike in appeals from federal workers facing layoffs, with over 2,000 cases received in the past two weeks. A National Institutes of Health employee, who was let go on Valentine's Day, is among those challenging their layoff. She said, 'They terminated me, saying that I was not meeting the requirements of my probationary period. I have my supervisor's review from the previous November stating that I was exceeding expectations, so my review and the termination letter do not match at all.' The employee's case is pending, and she has not seen any progress since filing her appeal on Feb. 19. The board's case load has skyrocketed since the wave of U.S. government layoffs began, with an average of 100 new cases per week before jumping to 578 cases in one week and 1,845 cases in another. The worker said one reason she's challenging her dismissal is due to the letter stating her job performance was to blame for her being fired. She added, 'I want my job back. I loved my job. I was proud of my job, and I didn't deserve to have it taken away.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 02:12 AM
Source:[WTOP](https://wtop.com/government/2025/02/amid-federal-layoffs-u-s-merit-systems-protection-board-sees-dramatic-spike-in-appeals-from-feds/)

**Amid federal layoffs, US Merit Systems Protection Board sees dramatic spike in appeals from feds**
Since the US government layoffs began, the US Merit Systems Protection Board has seen a dramatic spike in appeals from federal workers. Over the past two weeks, more than 2,000 cases have been received. A former NIH employee who was let go on Valentine's Day is among those challenging their layoff, citing a discrepancy between her supervisor's review and the termination letter. The employee, who wishes to remain anonymous, said she was rated 'Achieved More than Expected Results' or 'Achieved Outstanding Results' in every category, but was still terminated. She believes the termination letter is 'boiler plate text' and is challenging her dismissal. The worker is not alone, as many others are facing similar situations, with some even considering a class-action lawsuit against the federal government. The situation has left many in a tough spot, with bills continuing to come in despite the lack of paychecks.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 26, 2025 02:00 AM
Source:[wtop.com](https://wtop.com/government/2025/02/amid-federal-layoffs-u-s-merit-systems-protection-board-sees-dramatic-spike-in-appeals-from-feds/)

**Agency Head Court Shielded From Removal Is Publicly Pushing Against Trump Admin's Efforts**
Hampton Dellinger, head of the Office of Special Counsel, has publicly opposed the Trump administration's terminations of federal employees, stating that firing probationary employees without individual cause 'appears contrary to a reasonable reading of the law.' Dellinger, who was reinstated by a federal judge after being fired by President Trump, has filed requests to pause terminations for six probationary employees and is looking for ways to help others in the same position. The Supreme Court has allowed a temporary restraining order reinstating Dellinger to remain in place until February 26, when it is set to expire. Dellinger's organization, Democracy Forward, is also representing federal employees facing termination and will continue to urge the Office of Special Counsel and the U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board to follow the law and protect federal workers.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 25, 2025 03:52 PM
Source:[The Daily Caller](https://dailycaller.com/2025/02/25/hampton-dellinger-court-shielded-removal-publicly-pushing-against-trump-admins-efforts/)

**Elon Musk's Deadline for Federal Employees to Explain Their Achievements Passes**
Dellinger asked the US Merit Systems Protection Board to stop the layoffs of six federal employees, but hinted that many more workers should be protected from losing their jobs. There are also indications that Elon Musk is testing the limits of his influence. Some government officials, including some of Trump's closest allies, such as FBI Director Kash Patel, have told employees not to respond to the email asking them to explain five things they've accomplished, citing privacy or security concerns, and noting that agencies have their own processes for evaluating employees.
Original language: es
Publish date: February 25, 2025 01:07 PM
Source:[El Nuevo Día](https://www.elnuevodia.com/noticias/estados-unidos/notas/vence-el-plazo-dado-por-elon-musk-para-que-empleados-federales-expliquen-sus-logros/)

**‘No Illusions What We Are Up Against’**
Kamala Harris received the Chairman's Award at the 2025 NAACP Image Awards, where she was honored for her leadership and advocacy. Harris, a former vice president and 2024 Democratic presidential candidate, was introduced by NAACP board of directors chair Leon W. Russell, who praised her for her 'force of nature' campaign and her 'gratitude' from the NAACP. Harris spoke about the organization's origins and its continued importance in the face of adversity, saying 'We have no illusions about what we are up against in this chapter in our American story, but this chapter will not be written simply by whoever occupies the Oval Office or by the wealthiest among us. The American story will be written by you, by we the people.' The Chairman's Award recognizes individuals who have excelled in public service and driven meaningful change.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 23, 2025 03:24 AM
Source:[clichemag.com](https://clichemag.com/entertainment/no-illusions-what-we-are-up-against/)

**Trump Administration Appeals Against Order to Reinstate Merit Systems Board Chair**
The Trump administration has appealed against a district court judge's order to reinstate Cathy Harris as chairwoman of the U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB). The judge's order temporarily restored Harris to her position and prohibited government officials from treating her as having been removed. Harris's counsel argued that she could only be terminated for 'inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office' and that she was not given a reason for her termination. The government attorneys argue that President Trump had the ability to fire MSPB members at will and that Harris's attorneys fell short of making a strong enough showing that she would succeed on merits in her position. They claim that the president is being prevented from installing an agency head of his choosing and that this harm is irreparable to the Executive Branch and the separation of powers.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 20, 2025 11:11 PM
Source:[www.theepochtimes.com](https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/trump-administration-appeals-against-order-to-reinstate-merit-systems-board-chair-5813526)

**Judge halts Trump's effort to fire Democrat from government workplace board**
A federal judge has temporarily reinstated Cathy Harris, a Democrat who was fired by President Trump as the chair of the Merit Systems Protection Board. The judge, Rudolph Contreras, issued a temporary restraining order, citing that Trump's attempt to fire Harris likely violated federal law. Harris was appointed to the board in 2022 by President Biden and served as its chair until Trump took office. The case is one of several brought by chairs or members of independent boards who have been fired by Trump, and will likely test the scope of the president's powers over those agencies. As Harris' lawyer, Michael Kator, said, 'This is an extraordinarily important first step.' The judge scheduled a hearing for March 3 to continue allowing Harris to remain on the board pending the outcome of the case.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 04:37 PM
Source:[usatoday.com](https://eu.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2025/02/19/judge-blocks-trump-fire-democrat-federal-workplace-board/79191089007/)

**Fired Top Federal Employee Ordered Back To Work**
Cathy Harris, the chair of the federal Merit Systems Protection Board, has been reinstated to her position after a federal lawsuit was filed against her dismissal by President Donald Trump. U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras agreed that the Trump administration had no authority to initiate her dismissal, citing that the government may only fire someone in that position for 'inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.' Harris' attorney, Linda Correia, argued that none of those factors were alleged by the government in the firing notice. Contreras has ordered both sides to prepare for another hearing on the case in early March, and Harris is currently allowed to carry out the responsibilities of the position without interference.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 12:31 AM
Source:[NewsMax](https://www.newsmax.com/newsfront/federal-employee-reinstated/2025/02/18/id/1199600/)

**Judge Orders Trump Admin to Reinstate Fired Merit Systems Protection Board Chair**
A federal judge has ordered President Donald Trump and other federal officials to reinstate Cathy A. Harris as chairwoman of the U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board. U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras ruled that Harris can only be removed 'for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office,' citing a 1935 Supreme Court ruling known as Humphrey's Executor. Contreras stated that Harris is likely to succeed in her lawsuit and that she would suffer irreparable harm without the restraining order. The relief is temporary, and Harris can ask for a preliminary injunction, which would be more permanent as the case proceeds.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 12:29 AM
Source:[www.theepochtimes.com](https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/judge-orders-trump-admin-to-reinstate-fired-merit-systems-protection-board-chair-5812254)

**Judge stops Trump ouster of Merit Systems Protection Board chair**
A federal judge has ordered the reinstatement of Cathy Harris, the chair of the Merit Systems Protection Board, after the Trump administration fired her without providing a reason. U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras ruled that the administration had not articulated adequate grounds for her removal, citing federal law that states a board member may be removed only for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. Harris has until Feb. 23 to file a motion for a preliminary injunction, which would keep her in place on a longer-term basis. Tom Devine, legal director at Government Accountability Project, said, 'The merit system exists to ensure government service is about taxpayers — not politics. Undermining its ability to function through unjust firings doesn’t prevent waste and fraud: it is waste, and it is fraud.' Harris expressed optimism, saying, 'I’m feeling confident that the rule of law will prevail,' and that she expects to return to her position.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[washingtonpost.com](https://www.washingtonpost.com/dc-md-va/2025/02/18/merit-systems-protection-board-cathy-harris-restored-trump-ouster/)

**Obama Judge Reinstates Biden-Appointed Chairwoman of Merit Systems Protection Board, Says Trump Doesn’t Have Authority to Fire Her**
A federal judge, Judge Rudolph Contreras, has reinstated Cathy Harris, the Democrat chairwoman of the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB), who was fired by President Donald Trump earlier this month. According to Judge Contreras, Trump's decision to fire Harris exceeded his authority, as federal law states that members of the MSPB can only be removed for 'inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.' The MSPB's mission is to 'Protect the Merit System Principles and promote an effective Federal workforce free of Prohibited Personnel Practices.' Harris was appointed to the MSPB in 2021 and her term was set to expire on March 1, 2028.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 19, 2025 12:00 AM
Source:[noqreport.com](https://noqreport.com/just-in-obama-judge-reinstates-biden-appointed-chairwoman-of-merit-systems-protection-board-says-trump-doesnt-have-authority-to-fire-her/)

**JUST IN: Obama Judge Reinstates Biden-Appointed Chairwoman of Merit Systems Protection Board, Says Trump Doesn’t Have Authority to Fire Her**
A federal judge, Judge Rudolph Contreras, has reinstated Cathy Harris, the Democrat chairwoman of the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB), after President Donald Trump fired her earlier this month. According to Judge Contreras, Trump's decision to fire Harris exceeded his authority, as federal law states that members of the MSPB can only be removed for 'inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.' The MSPB's mission is to 'Protect the Merit System Principles and promote an effective Federal workforce free of Prohibited Personnel Practices,' as stated on the agency's website. Harris was appointed to the MSPB in 2021 and her term was set to expire on March 1, 2028.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 11:12 PM
Source:[Donald J. Trump](https://freerepublic.com/focus/f-bloggers/4298665/posts)

**Federal Judge Challenges Trump's Authority with Reinstatement Order | Law-Order**
A federal judge, Judge Rudolph Contreras, has temporarily reinstated Cathy Harris as the chair of the Merit Systems Protection Board, challenging President Trump's decision to fire her. This move raises questions about presidential powers to dismiss officials from independent agencies and could set significant precedents for future governance. The case may ultimately reach the Supreme Court, which could redefine the limits of presidential authority. As Harris' reinstatement impedes potential gridlock within the board, Trump's broader layoffs have met with union opposition and legal questions, closely watched by the Supreme Court.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 11:03 PM
Source:[Devdiscourse](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/3269787-federal-judge-challenges-trumps-authority-with-reinstatement-order)

**US judge blocks Trump's removal of Democrat from government workplace board By Reuters**
A federal judge has temporarily blocked the removal of Cathy Harris, a Democrat who served as the chair of the Merit Systems Protection Board, after President Donald Trump fired her. U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras issued a temporary restraining order, citing that Trump's attempt to fire Harris likely violated federal law. The judge stated that there is a 'substantial public interest in having governmental agencies abide by the federal laws that govern their existence and operations.' Harris was appointed to the board in 2022 by President Joe Biden and served as its chair until Trump took office. The reinstatement of Harris means the board would still have a quorum to decide cases after the term of the remaining Democrat, Raymond Limon, expires on March 1. As stated by Michael Kator, a lawyer for Harris, 'This is, of course, only the first step in a series of battles that almost certainly will culminate in the Supreme Court. But this is an extraordinarily important first step.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 11:02 PM
Source:[Investing.com](https://www.investing.com/news/world-news/us-judge-blocks-trump-from-removing-democrat-from-government-workplace-board-3875470)

**JUST IN: Obama Judge Reinstates Biden-Appointed Chairwoman of Merit Systems Protection Board, Says Trump Doesn't Have Authority to Fire Her | The Gateway Pundit | by Cristina Laila**
A federal judge, Judge Rudolph Contreras, has reinstated Cathy Harris, the Democrat chairwoman of the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB), after President Trump fired her earlier this month. Contreras stated that Trump's decision to fire Harris exceeded his authority, as federal law requires removal of MSPB members only for 'inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.' Harris was appointed to the MSPB in 2021 and her term was set to expire on March 1, 2028. The court has issued a temporary restraining order and ordered Harris to file a motion for a preliminary injunction by February 23, 2025. Trump's DOJ must file opposition by February 28, and Harris must reply by March 3.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 10:47 PM
Source:[The Gateway Pundit](https://www.thegatewaypundit.com/2025/02/obama-judge-reinstates-democrat-chairwoman-merit-systems-protection/)

**JUST IN: Obama Judge Reinstates Biden-Appointed Chairwoman of Merit Systems Protection Board, Says Trump Doesn’t Have Authority to Fire Her**
A federal judge, Judge Rudolph Contreras, has reinstated Cathy Harris, the Democrat chairwoman of the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB), after President Trump fired her earlier this month. Contreras said Trump's decision to fire Harris exceeded his authority, citing federal law that states members of the MSPB can only be removed for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office. The judge issued a temporary restraining order and ordered Harris to file a motion for a preliminary injunction by February 23, with Trump's DOJ to file opposition by February 28. The court will rule on a preliminary injunction as soon as possible after both parties have filed replies.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 10:40 PM
Source:[thegatewaypundit.com](https://www.thegatewaypundit.com/2025/02/obama-judge-reinstates-democrat-chairwoman-merit-systems-protection/)

**Federal Judge Reinstates Merit Board Chair Amid Legal Battle | Politics**
A federal judge has temporarily reinstated Cathy Harris, the former chair of the U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board, after her removal by President Trump. Judge Rudolph Contreras issued a restraining order to halt the administration's actions, citing the need to consider the legality of her dismissal and her ongoing lawsuit. Harris argues that her dismissal was unlawful, and the case highlights the ongoing legal scrutiny surrounding administrative dismissals and the checks and balances between different governmental branches.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 08:57 PM
Source:[Devdiscourse](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3269733-federal-judge-reinstates-merit-board-chair-amid-legal-battle)

**Federal Judge Reinstates Merit Board Chair Amid Legal Battle**
A federal judge has temporarily reinstated Cathy Harris, the former chair of the U.S. Merit Systems Protection Board, who was removed by President Donald Trump. Judge Rudolph Contreras issued a restraining order to halt the administration's actions, citing Harris' argument that her dismissal was unlawful. The decision highlights the ongoing legal scrutiny surrounding administrative dismissals and the checks and balances between different governmental branches. Harris' lawsuit will now proceed as scheduled in the District of Columbia.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 18, 2025 08:55 PM
Source:[devdiscourse.com](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3269733-federal-judge-reinstates-merit-board-chair-amid-legal-battle)

**Member of US government employee appeals board sues over Trump firing**
Cathy Harris, a Democrat and former chair of the Merit Systems Protection Board, has filed a lawsuit against President Donald Trump after he attempted to fire her. Harris, who was appointed to the board in 2022, claims that Trump's decision to fire her was unlawful and contravened nearly a century of legal precedent. According to Harris, she can only be removed 'for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office,' which Trump's one-sentence email did not meet. This is the latest instance of an official with an independent agency going to court after Trump said he was axing them. Harris is asking a federal judge in Washington to issue an emergency temporary restraining order reinstating her.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 12, 2025 04:03 PM
Source:[Daily Mail Online](https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-14389923/Member-US-government-employee-appeals-board-sues-Trump-firing.html)

forecasters.initial_reasoning: The Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) plays a crucial role in safeguarding federal employees' rights and ensuring merit-based personnel practices. Historically, changes in leadership positions like the Chair of the MSPB can be influenced by political transitions (such as new presidential administrations) and significant legal rulings. Cathy Harris, having been reinstated by a federal judge, indicates legal backing to hold her position. Historically, once reinstated and barring significant political shifts or compelling legal challenges, chairs of federal boards typically remain in their roles. Therefore, based on historical stability of similar positions following legal reinstatements, the base probability of Cathy Harris still being the chair by March 31, 2025, is estimated at approximately 70%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Judicial Reinstatement
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Being reinstated by a federal judge often grants significant job security barring any newfound legal issues or higher court interventions. This judicial backing provides a strong basis for remaining in the position.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Environment Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Given that it is early in the presidential term and no major changes have been announced in federal employment policy, the political environment is likely stable enough that there would be minimal motivation to replace the chair.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Lack of Precedent for Removal Post-Reinstatement
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: There is a limited historical precedent for chairs being removed shortly after judicial reinstatement without notable cause. This stability historically tends to maintain the position status quo.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Potential Emerging Legal Challenges
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Although unlikely, unforeseen legal challenges or court rulings could arise, potentially jeopardizing the recent judicial ruling. Previous events suggest a minimal chance, but it's not nil.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several articles confirm that Cathy Harris has been reinstated by a federal judge after being unlawfully dismissed by President Trump. This includes affirmations that her dismissal exceeded the authority given the legal standard requiring removal 'for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance in office.' These elements bolster the judiciary's protection of her role, increasing the likelihood of her continued tenure.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The Trump administration has actively appealed against the reinstatement order, challenging the judicial decision that ruled in favor of Harris. This legal challenge poses a potential risk to her position should the appeal succeed or result in a different judicial interpretation. However, no immediate removal or judicial decision has been made against her yet, maintaining her reinstated status.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: To estimate the initial probability of Cathy Harris still chairing the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) on March 31, 2025, I will consider historical base rates of federal agency chairs being replaced or maintaining their positions within similar timeframes. Historically, leadership positions in federal agencies like the MSPB have some stability, especially over short periods, unless there is significant political or legal upheaval. Assuming a moderate turnover rate for agency leaders within a year due to changes in administration or political shifts, I estimate a base rate of 70% for agency chairs remaining in their roles over three months.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current political environment does not indicate a major upheaval or a significant change in the administration that would typically lead to changes in key agency positions. This stability suggests a higher likelihood that Cathy Harris will remain in her role.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Legal Precedent
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The federal judge's decision to reinstate Cathy Harris suggests legal support for her position, adding a layer of protection against arbitrary dismissal, thereby increasing the likelihood of her continuation as chair.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Performance Factors
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Assuming no negative reports on Harris’s performance have emerged, her ongoing leadership and any recognition of her effective management would further support her retention.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Potential Administrative Overhaul
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: While currently unlikely, any emerging political need for administrative restructuring by the government could pose a risk, but no current signs strongly suggest this is probable before March 31, 2025.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The federal judge's ruling to reinstate Cathy Harris and block her dismissal reinforces the initial analysis of legal protection, substantiating the argument that federal law protects her position and making her removal before March 31, 2025, less likely.
revised_reasoning.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The Trump administration's active appeal against the judge's ruling introduces uncertainty regarding the stability of Harris's position, potentially impacting her ability to maintain her role.

forecasters.initial_reasoning: Historically, appointments to positions like the chair of the Merit Systems Protection Board (MSPB) have relatively stable tenures, especially when not influenced by a change in administration. Removing a chair within such a short timeframe, without a significant political or performance issue, is uncommon. Typically, chairs in these positions hold their roles until a new administration takes over if they are aligned politically or perform adequately. Based on historical frequencies, the probability of a chair being replaced within a year of appointment, absent political or performance controversies, is low, around 20%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Political Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Unless there is significant turnover or conflict within the administration or agency, the likelihood of Harris losing her position is low. This stability tends to maintain officials in their positions unless extenuating circumstances arise.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Legal Stability
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Cathy Harris has recently been reinstated, suggesting legal backing for her position. The court's decision provides a reinforced legal standing, making her removal much less probable without substantial cause.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Policy Alignment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: If Harris's policy decisions and performance are aligned with the current administration’s priorities and demonstrate efficiency, it bolsters her position further, reducing the likelihood of any abrupt changes.

revised_reasoning.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: A federal judge has reinstated Cathy Harris, emphasizing that her removal was likely unlawful and against federal law requiring specific grounds for dismissal. This action suggests strong judicial backing for her continued role, which reinforces the prediction that she will remain as chair through March 31, 2025. Additionally, legal opinions and the actions of Judge Contreras indicate that Harris's position is protected unless inefficiency, neglect of duty, or malfeasance can be proved, which has not yet been demonstrated.

However, this challenge currently lacks substantive developments to immediately influence the forecast.

Historically, once appointees are confirmed, they are typically stable in their roles barring significant political shifts or personal decisions to step down. For instance, leadership positions in federal agencies are generally retained through their term unless there's a change in administration or significant internal pressure. I estimate this base rate probability to be around 70%.

Public statements from her legal team and other officials about the legality of her removal further solidify this stance.
